III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of Staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth K reportedly misused social media on a device at the facility
alleging inadequate staff supervision.
Investigation I left a voice message informing Complainant I was assigned this
investigation alleging inadequate supervision by Vista Maria staff.
I did not hear back from Complainant.
I notified Foster Care Worker 1, and Foster Care Worker 2 who is
covering in Foster Care Worker 1’s absence, via email that I was
assigned this investigation.
I notified Placement Collaboration Unit via email that Dearborn
Heights Police took a report from Youth K on 4/18/23 at 4:30pm.
Case #23-10838
I notified Vista Maria’s Rights Officer of the allegation against
Vista Maria.
I requested and reviewed Vista Maria’s Semi-Independent Living
(SIL) Program Handbook for Myriam Hall youth. The handbook
indicates electronics are allowed (cell phone, laptop, tablet,
gaming system) after the youth successfully completes the first 14
days of orientation.
2

Youth K was admitted to Myriam Hall on 2/22/23 and completed
the orientation on 3/8/23. Thus, she was allowed to use
electronics at the time this allegation was received.
The handbook also indicates the following regarding social media:
Residents are not allowed to share information of a resident, not
allowed to send personal messages of an individual to peers on
campus and people in the community, not allowed to face time a
resident when talking with an individual off campus, and not
allowed to video/audio record a resident/tenant. This rule also
applies to social media of staff. Overall, any forms of electronic
communication (social networking, microblogging, photo sharing,
video sharing, book marking sites, etc.) of an individual on
campus are prohibited (not allowed to happen).
I interviewed Youth K, age 17 years and 11 months, on 4/18/23
with Rights Officer present. She is cognitively impaired with
mental health issues and has resided in various programs on
Vista Maria’s campus since July 2019. Youth K admitted that two
to four weeks ago in Myriam Hall, she used her facility-issued
computer to communicate with a male (age unknown, possibly 16
- 22). Contrary to the SIL handbook, she said she believed that
after 30 days in the program, “we can contact anyone or send
anything” via electronic device. Youth K did not appear to recall
the program’s written rules for social media use.
Youth K said that staff at the facility did not monitor her device use
or internet activity after she completed orientation because they
are not supposed to. However, after her sister told Therapist that
Youth K had internet exchanges with a male, she said Therapist
confiscated her computer on 4/17/23. “I won’t be using that
computer anymore,” Youth K added.
I interviewed Therapist on 4/18/23 with Rights Officer present.
She said Youth K was just transferred to her caseload one week
prior. Therapist confirmed she confiscated Youth K’s computer
after the youth’s sister claimed Youth K had interacted
inappropriately with a male on the internet who the sister believed
to be an adult. Therapist said, “I talked to Foster Care Worker 2
and her GAL (guardian ad-litem) approved us to remove the
computer. We recommended the sister report this to the
police…She (Youth K’s sister) reported it to CPS.” However, to
Therapist’s knowledge, no one had reported it to law enforcement
to date.
3

I asked Therapist to contact Dearborn Heights Police immediately
and file a formal police report. Before I left the facility Therapist
told me she contacted the police, and they were on their way to
Myriam Hall to interview Youth K and take her statement. Later
that day, Therapist informed me via email that a police officer
arrived and had taken a report.
Analysis In terms of staff failing to supervise Youth K’s internet and device
activity, there is no requirement for staff to supervise devices for
SIL youth. After completing orientation, youth are trusted to
monitor their own activity in accordance with the social media rule
in the SIL handbook.
Additionally, however, upon receipt of information that Youth K
had potentially misused this privilege, Therapist confiscated her
computer/device.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
